Reports a suspicious combination of + or - characters in JavaScript code (for example, a+++b. Such sequences are confusing, and their semantics may change through changes in the whitespace.

Reports a block statement that is not used as the body of if, for, while, do, with, or try statements, or as the body of a function declaration. Starting from ECMAScript 6, JavaScript blocks introduce new scopes for let and const variables, but still free-standing block statements may be confusing and result in subtle bugs when used with var variables.

inspection.displayName: Result of increment or decrement used

group.inspection: Reports an increment (++) or decrement (--) expression where the result of the assignment is used in a containing expression. Such assignments can result in confusion due to the order of operations, as evaluation of the assignment may affect the outer expression in unexpected ways. Example: var a = b++

Reports a boolean expression with too many terms. Such expressions may be confusing and bug-prone.

Use the field below to specify the maximum number of terms allowed in an arithmetic expression.
Reports if statements which have an else branch and a negated condition. Flipping the order of the if and else branches will usually increase the clarity of such statements.

Reports an arithmetic expression with too many terms. Such expressions may be confusing and bug-prone.

Use the field below to specify the maximum number of terms allowed in an arithmetic expression.

group.name: Rust
group.inspection: Reports invalid `Copy` implementations. The `Copy` trait can only be implemented for structs, enums, and unions. E0206

inspection.displayName: Inherent `impl` block not allowed for item

group.inspection: Reports inherent `impl` blocks defined for items other than structs, enums, unions, or trait objects. <!-- tooltip end -->

Checks if the right number of generic arguments was used for a type, trait, function call or method call.
Corresponds to the E0107 Rust error.

Reports calls to std::mem::drop with a reference instead of an owned value.
Corresponds to the drop_ref lint from Rust Clippy.
Reports module declarations with no corresponding file found. <!-- tooltip end -->
Reports enums that require a `#[repr(inttype)]` attribute. <!-- tooltip end -->
Reports incorrect use of `impl Trait`. Abstract return types are only allowed as function and inherent impl return types. <!-- tooltip end -->
<html> <body> Reports unresolved method references. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>
Reports functions that cannot be declared variadic. <!-- tooltip end -->
Reports the use of the `self` keyword in static methods. <!-- tooltip end -->

inspection.displayName: Variadic parameters for non-C ABI function

group.inspection: Reports C-variadic functions that do not use a compatible calling convention. <!-- tooltip end -->
Reports the use of `++` and `--` operators, which are not supported in Rust. <!-- tooltip end -->
Reports modules declared as unsafe. <!-- tooltip end -->
Reports `inline` attributes applied to items other than functions or closures. <!-- tooltip end -->
<html> <body> Reports unresolved path references. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>
Reports labels with invalid names. <!-- tooltip end -->
Reports usages of dbg! macro.
<html> <body> Reports invalid attempts to access private fields or methods. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>
Reports basic borrow checker errors. <!-- tooltip end -->

Reports calls to std::mem::drop with values that derive the Copy trait.
Corresponds to the dropping_copy_types lint.
<html> <body> Detects incomplete attributes that require parentheses. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>
Reports errors when calling macros. <!-- tooltip end -->

inspection.displayName: Wrong number of type or const parameters

group.inspection:
Checks if an attempted implementation of a trait method or an associated type has the right number of type or const parameters.
Corresponds to the E0049 Rust error.
<html> <body> Detects files that are not attached to any Rust module. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>
Reports the use of `break`/`continue` keywords without labels in `while` loop conditions. <!-- tooltip end -->

inspection.displayName: Forward-declared identifier for parameter with default value

group.inspection: Reports generic parameters with default values that use forward-declared identifiers. E0128
Detects assignments to immutable. Corresponds to E0594 Rust error.
Reports explicit calls to `drop`. It is not allowed to manually call destructors in Rust. <!-- tooltip end -->
Check if the crate name is valid, namely the crate name must not be empty, and must only contain Unicode alphanumeric or _ (U+005F) characters.
Reports `main` functions defined with generic parameters. <!-- tooltip end -->
Reports invalid usages of break and continue in loops.
Reports incorrect usage of the ? operator.
Reports cases where field initialization shorthand (RFC 1682) can be used.
Reports incorrect type alias syntax. <!-- tooltip end -->
Reports if and match statements that can be converted to expressions by lifting a return out.
Reports members that do not implement the traits being derived. <!-- tooltip end -->

inspection.displayName: Type placeholder used in item signature

group.inspection: Reports the use of type placeholders (_) in an item's signature.
Reports the use of unsafe items in a safe context. <!-- tooltip end -->
Reports format! calls with missing format arguments.
Reports inherent implementations marked as unsafe. <!-- tooltip end -->
Reports the use of `self` in contexts where it is not available. <!-- tooltip end -->
Reports explicit implementations of the `Sized` and `Unsized` traits. <!-- tooltip end -->
Finds usages of the try! macro which can be replaced with ? operator starting from Rust 1.13.0.
Reports the use of unstable items. <!-- tooltip end -->

inspection.displayName: Item cannot be inside another item

group.inspection: Reports structs, enums, macro definitions and traits placed inside other structs, enums, macro definitions or traits. <!-- tooltip end -->
Reports issues with attributes including misuse, redundancy, formatting errors, invalid entries, outdated syntax, and more. <!-- tooltip end -->
Reports implementations of foreign traits (traits defined outside the current crate) for arbitrary types. <!-- tooltip end -->
Reports the use of anonymous parameters in functions that do not allow it. <!-- tooltip end -->

inspection.displayName: Inherent `impl` defined outside type's containing crate

group.inspection: Reports inherent type implementations defined outside the type's original crate. <!-- tooltip end -->

inspection.displayName: Multiple relaxed default bounds for type parameter

group.inspection: Reports type parameters with multiple relaxed default bounds. Only a single relaxed default bound is supported. <!-- tooltip end -->

Reports the use of #[proc_macro], #[proc_macro_attribute], and #[proc_macro_derive] attributes in non-procedural macro crates. These attributes only work for procedural macro crates (i.e. crates with the proc-macro key set to true in Cargo.toml).
Reports function calls with an incorrect number of arguments. <!-- tooltip end -->
Detect assert!(a == b) (and assert!(a != b)) macro call that can be simplified into assert_eq!(a, b) (or assert_ne!(a, b)).
Reports trait bounds for a single type that are separated with a comma instead of a `+` sign. <!-- tooltip end -->
Reports recursion used in async functions without boxing. E0733
Checks if the main function exists in the binary crates.
Reports redundant ::.
The Rust type checker (experimental). <!-- tooltip end -->
Reports the use of `...` deprecated syntax. <!-- tooltip end -->
Reports errors in trait implementation like "Missing members", "Unknown member", etc. <!-- tooltip end -->
<html> <body> Reports unresolved path references. This inspection can report false positives. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>
Reports `extern crate self` that is not followed by `as <name>`. <!-- tooltip end -->
Detects usage of thread_rng().gen() that can be replaced with random() from rand crate.

inspection.displayName: Type mismatched the trait's associated type

group.inspection: A type mismatched an associated type of a trait. <!-- tooltip end -->
Reports union declarations with tuple syntax. <!-- tooltip end -->
Detects implementations of ToString trait which, as its documentation states, shouldn't be implemented directly and Display trait should be implemented instead.

inspection.displayName: Attempt to call not a function

group.inspection: When calling somethings, checks that it is function or method. <!-- tooltip end -->
Reports invalid `self` imports. <!-- tooltip end -->
Reports lifetime bounds in parentheses. <!-- tooltip end -->

Detects boolean expressions that can be safely simplified like a || true.
Does not simplify expressions if some side effects can be eliminated, such as return || true for example.

inspection.displayName: Non-structural-match type used for const generic parameter

group.inspection: Reports the use of non-structural-match types for const generic parameters. Only structural-match types (types that derive PartialEq and Eq and implement ConstParamTy) can be used for const generic parameters.

inspection.displayName: A non-constant value was used in a constant expression

group.inspection: Reports a non-constant value or function call used in a constant expression. <!-- tooltip end -->
Detects unsafe usage of CString. The code like CString::new("hello").unwrap().as_ptr() may lead to memory unsafety because the string is deallocated at the end of the expression.
Detects else-statements preceded by irrefutable patterns.
Reports `return;` statements contained in functions whose return type is not `()`. E0069
Reports missing supertrait implementations. E0277
Reports incorrect use of the literal `crate` in a path. The `crate` literal is only allowed at the beginning of the path. <!-- tooltip end -->
Reports struct fields declared without a type. <!-- tooltip end -->
Reports invalid `Drop` implementations. The `Drop` trait can only be implemented for structs and enums. E0120
Reports function parameters whose types are unknown at compile time. <!-- tooltip end -->
<html> <body> Checks duplicated parameter names of abstract trait methods. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>
Reports struct inheritance, which is not supported in Rust. <!-- tooltip end -->
Reports attempts to access non-existent fields. E0609, E0610, E0615

inspection.displayName: `_` on the right-hand side of assignment

group.inspection: Reports invalid use of underscores (`_`) in expressions: they are only allowed on the left-hand side of an assignment. <!-- tooltip end -->
Reports incorrect use of patterns in functions. <!-- tooltip end -->
Reports incorrect field use in struct literals. <!-- tooltip end -->
Reports non-string ABI literals. <!-- tooltip end -->

inspection.displayName: Generic arguments must be specified before the first constraint

group.inspection: Reports generic arguments specified after the first constraint. <!-- tooltip end -->
Reports failed function calls or assertions in tests. It helps detect the failed line in code faster and start debugging it immediately. <!-- tooltip end -->

inspection.displayName: `with` call can be replaced with thread local stable method

group.inspection: Detects usages of LocalKey::with() method that can be replaced with stable thread local methods.
Reports captures of a dynamic environment in a `fn` item. <!-- tooltip end -->
<html> <body> Reports unresolved method references. This inspection can report false positives. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>
Reports the use of reserved lifetime names. <!-- tooltip end -->
Reports undeclared lifetimes. <!-- tooltip end -->

Detects suspiciously looking if-statements with potentially missing elses.
Partially corresponds to suspicious_else_formatting lint from Rust Clippy.
Check if the index of an array is out of bounds. let mut array: [i32; 3] = [0; 3]; array[4]; .
Reports undeclared labels. <!-- tooltip end -->
Reports trait objects declared without a single trait. <!-- tooltip end -->

Checks if correct associated type arguments were used for a type or a trait reference.
Corresponds to the E0191 and E0220 Rust errors.
Reports the use of `self` and `super` keywords not at the beginning of the path. <!-- tooltip end -->
Reports inherent implementations for dynamic auto traits. E0785

inspection.displayName: Invalid fields in struct or tuple struct pattern

group.inspection: Reports invalid fields in struct and tuple struct patterns. <!-- tooltip end -->
Reports `derive` attributes applied to items other than structs, enums, or unions. <!-- tooltip end -->

inspection.displayName: Defaults for const parameters not allowed

group.inspection: Reports invalid use of defaults for const parameters. They are only allowed in struct, enum, type, and trait definitions. <!-- tooltip end -->
Checks that match expression is exhaustive, i.e. all possible patterns are covered.
Reports incorrectly ordered lifetime, type, and const parameters. <!-- tooltip end -->

inspection.displayName: Non-inline module declaration missing path attribute

group.inspection: Reports non-inline modules declared inside a block and missing the path attribute. <!-- tooltip end -->
Reports duplicate items (such as field declarations, type parameters, etc.). <!-- tooltip end -->
Reports variadic functions where `...` is not positioned as the last argument. <!-- tooltip end -->
Reports hard coded numeric constants such as std::f64::consts::PI. Corresponds to approx_constant lint from Rust Clippy.
<html> <body> Detects Cargo packages with missing cargo features in some of their dependency packages <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>
Reports module declarations in files other than mod.rs. <!-- tooltip end -->
Detects usages of println!("") which can be simplified to println!() since from Rust 1.14.0.
Reports non-trait items referenced as traits. <!-- tooltip end -->
Checks if the entry point of the program was marked as async.
<html> <body> This inspection runs external linter to check for rustc or clippy errors. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>
Reports `let` expressions in places where they are unsupported. <!-- tooltip end -->
<html> <body> Highlights `compile_error!()` macro invocation. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>

Detects suspiciously looking else if-statements split by new lines.
Partially corresponds to suspicious_else_formatting lint from Rust Clippy.
Reports invalid fragment specifier of a macro variable. <!-- tooltip end -->
Reports private items that were re-exported publicly. <!-- tooltip end -->
Reports incorrect visibility restrictions. <!-- tooltip end -->
Reports mismatches between the safety of a trait's definition and its implementation. <!-- tooltip end -->
Some unstable experimental checks which are disabled by default. <!-- tooltip end -->
Reports code that uses unavailable compiler features. <!-- tooltip end -->
Reports the use of keywords reserved in Rust 2024 edition, as well as features unavailable in Rust 2024 edition. <!-- tooltip end -->
Reports `crate` used in paths. <!-- tooltip end -->

Reports the use of types that do not implement the necessary traits. This inspection covers more cases than `Type does not implement trait`, however it may produce false positives. <!-- tooltip end -->
Reports where clauses containing nested quantification over lifetimes, which is not supported.

Detects use of the non-existent =*, =! and =- operators that are probably typos.
Corresponds to suspicious_assignment_formatting lint from Rust Clippy.
Reports unreachable labels. <!-- tooltip end -->

Reports circular module declarations with the #path attribute. Such declarations produce an infinite module graph and cannot be compiled. A common example of this error is a file module that declares a child mod referencing the current file:
// File: recursive_mod.rs
#[path = "recursive_mod.rs"]
mod child_mod;
Reports the use of nested `impl Trait`. `impl Trait` types cannot appear nested in the generic arguments of other `impl Trait` types. <!-- tooltip end -->
Reports chained comparison operators with missing parentheses. <!-- tooltip end -->

inspection.displayName: Reserved keyword used as an identifier

group.inspection: Reports the use of reserved keywords. <!-- tooltip end -->
<html> <body> Checks duplicated patterns in macro definitions. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>
Reports discriminant values that are present more than once in a single enum. <!-- tooltip end -->
Reports the use of default parameter values, which are not supported in Rust. <!-- tooltip end -->

inspection.displayName: Index expression has a wrong type

group.inspection: Checks type of index expression. <!-- tooltip end -->
Highlights .. expression inside struct literal without base expression after it.
Reports cases where the `Copy` trait is implemented along with `Drop`, which is considered unsafe and currently not allowed in the Rust language. E0184
Reports the use of `break`/`continue` keywords outside `loop`/`while` blocks. <!-- tooltip end -->
Checks if members in the impl have a same order as in the trait. <!-- tooltip end -->

inspection.displayName: Use of `dyn`/`impl Trait` in type parameter bounds

group.inspection: Reports the use of `dyn` and `impl Trait` in type parameter bounds. <!-- tooltip end -->
Checks if the right number of lifetime parameters was used for a type or trait. Corresponds to E0106 / E0107 Rust errors.

inspection.displayName: Inclusive range without an end bound

group.inspection: Reports inclusive ranges without a specified end bound (`..=b` or `a..=b`). <!-- tooltip end -->
Reports unclosed text literals. <!-- tooltip end -->
Reports incorrect const syntax. <!-- tooltip end -->
Reports the use of types that do not implement the necessary traits. <!-- tooltip end -->
Reports incorrect function syntax. <!-- tooltip end -->

inspection.displayName: Blocking `sleep` function cannot be used in `async` context

group.inspection: Detects usages of blocking thread::sleep() function in async contexts.
Report incorrect usage of default type parameters. <!-- tooltip end -->
Reports unnecessary visibility qualifiers. <!-- tooltip end -->

inspection.displayName: Multiple lifetime bounds for trait object

group.inspection: Reports trait objects with multiple lifetime bounds. <!-- tooltip end -->
Checks if trait objects are explicitly specified with dyn keyword.
Reports invalid `default` keyword placement. <!-- tooltip end -->

inspection.displayName: Char literal empty or too long

group.inspection: Reports char literals which are empty or too long. <!-- tooltip end -->

Generic arguments were not provided in the same order as the corresponding generic parameters are declared.
Corresponds to the E0747 Rust error.
Reports invalid place expressions. For example: 1 + 1 = 2.
The Rust type checker. <!-- tooltip end -->

inspection.displayName: Additional non-auto trait in trait object

group.inspection: Reports trait objects with additional non-auto traits. In trait objects, only auto traits can be added as additional traits. <!-- tooltip end -->
Reports the use of unlabeled `break`/`continue` statements inside labeled blocks. <!-- tooltip end -->
Reports the use of `async` non-`move` closures with parameters for Rust 1.76 or earlier versions that do not support it. <!-- tooltip end -->
Reports the use of keywords reserved in Rust 2018 edition, as well as features unavailable in Rust 2018 edition. <!-- tooltip end -->
Reports identifiers bound more than once in the same pattern. <!-- tooltip end -->

inspection.displayName: Const generic argument expression without braces

group.inspection: Reports const generic argument expressions with missing braces. <!-- tooltip end -->
Reports public items located in the root of a procedural macro crate and not marked with a #[proc_macro], #[proc_macro_attribute], or #[proc_macro_derive] attribute. <!-- tooltip end -->
Reports errors in the use of macros that support formatting. <!-- tooltip end -->
Checks that union expr has exactly one field. <!-- tooltip end -->
Reports manual implementations of `Fn`, `FnMut`, and `FnOnce` traits. Such implementations are unstable and require a #![feature(fn_traits, unboxed_closures)] attribute.
Reports constant declarations with missing types. <!-- tooltip end -->
Check if a numerical value is out of the range of the receiver. For example: let x: u8 = 256;.

inspection.displayName: Match expression can be replaced with a method call

group.inspection: <html lang="en"> <body> Reports match expressions that can be replaced with a method call. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>
Detects immutable bindings reassignments. Corresponds to E0384 Rust error.
Reports lifetimes with invalid names. <!-- tooltip end -->
Reports the use of `self` as a function parameter in case it is not allowed. <!-- tooltip end -->
Reports literals with invalid suffixes. <!-- tooltip end -->
<html> <body> Reports duplicate keys when creating hash maps. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>
Reports if expressions that have true or false constant literal condition and can be simplified.

Detects expressions of the form --x which might be mistook for pre-decrements.
Corresponds to double_neg lint from Rust Clippy.
Detects constant variables that refer to static variables. Corresponds to E0013 Rust error.

group.name: Dev Container
group.inspection: <html> <body> Checks nested .devcontainer folders with ambiguous Dev Container context or a missing parent .devcontainer folder where it is needed. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>
<html> <body> Validates IDE settings names and values. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>

group.name: Cargo.toml
group.inspection: <html> <body> Reports crates that are not used in the project's source code. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>
<html> <body> Reports any unknown crates listed in Cargo.toml. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>
<html> <body> Detects features that depend on themselves. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>

Reports unnecessary package key in dependency declaration in Cargo.toml. package key is usually used for renaming the dependency. So, it can be removed when package key value is the same to the name of the dependency.

Reports duplicated keys within the same section of a Cargo.toml file.

Example:


  [foo]
  bar = 1 # Property redefinition is not allowed
  bar = 2 # Property redefinition is not allowed
<html> <body> Reports invalid crate versions in Cargo.toml. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>
<html> <body> Reports errors in Cargo.toml related to structure, constraints, and data types. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>
<html> <body> Reports outdated crate versions in Cargo.toml. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>
<html> <body> Reports string literals that are missing a closing quote. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>

Checks the categories field in the [package] section of Cargo.toml against the crates.io rules:
  • The categories must be chosen from the list of valid category slugs
  • A maximum of 5 categories is allowed

group.name: Invalid elements
group.inspection: <html> <body> Reports a negative value of a CSS property that is not expected to be less than zero, for example, object width or height. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>
Reports a CSS type selector that matches an unknown HTML element.
<html> <body> Reports an unknown unit. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>
Reports an unknown CSS at-rule.
Reports a misplaced @charset at-rule or an incorrect charset value.
Reports an unknown CSS media feature or an incorrect media feature value.
<html> <body> Reports an incorrect CSS property value. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>

Reports a misplaced @import statement.

According to the specification, an @import rule must be defined at the top of the stylesheet, before any other at-rule (except @charset and @layer) and style declarations, or it will be ignored.
Reports an incorrect CSS pseudo-class pseudo-element.
Reports an unresolved reference to a custom property among the arguments of the var() function.
Reports a missing required syntax, inherits, or initial-value property in a declaration of a custom property.

Reports a CSS class reference in the 'composes' rule that cannot be resolved to any valid target.

Example:


  .className {/* ... */}

  .otherClassName {
    composes: className;
  }
<html> <body> Reports a nested selector starting with an identifier or a functional notation. <!-- tooltip end --> </body> </html>

Reports an invalid custom property name. Custom property name should be prefixed with two dashes.

Example:


@property invalid-property-name {
  ...
}

@property --valid-property-name {
  ...
}
Reports an unknown CSS function or an incorrect function parameter.
Reports an unresolved file reference, for example, an incorrect path in an @import statement.

Reports an unknown CSS property or a property used in a wrong context.

Add the unknown property to the 'Custom CSS properties' list to skip validation.

group.name: PostCSS
group.inspection:
Checks range context syntax, which may alternatively be used for media features with a 'range' type.

Example:


@media screen and (500px <= width <= 1200px) {}

Reports a syntax error in a PostCSS Custom Media query.

Example:


@custom-media --small-viewport (max-width: 30em);

Reports a nested style rule whose syntax doesn't comply with the PostCSS Nested or the PostCSS Nesting specification.

Example:


.phone {
  &_title {}
}

Reports an unresolved reference to a CSS Module Value (@value declaration).

Example:


@value foo from unknown;

Reports a syntax error in PostCSS Custom Selector.

Example:


@custom-selector :--heading h1, h2, h3;

group.name: Bitwise operation issues
group.inspection: Reports an expression that includes and with zero, or by zero, or shifting by zero. Such expressions may result from not fully completed automated refactorings.

inspection.displayName: Shift operation by possibly wrong constant

group.inspection: Reports a shift operation where the second operand is a constant outside the reasonable range, for example, an integer shift operation outside the range 0..31, shifting by negative or overly large values.
Reports a suspicious usage of a bitwise AND ("&") or OR ("|") operator. Usually it is a typo and the result of applying boolean operations AND ("&&") and OR ("||") is expected.

Reports a bitwise mask expression which for sure evaluates to true or false. Expressions are of the form (var & constant1) == constant2 or (var | constant1) == constant2, where constant1 and constant2 are incompatible bitmask constants.

Example:


// Incompatible mask: as the last byte in mask is zero,
// something like 0x1200 would be possible, but not 0x1234
if ((mask & 0xFF00) == 0x1234) {...}

group.name: Try statement issues
group.inspection:
Reports an empty catch block. This indicates that errors are simply ignored instead of handling them.

Any comment in a catch block mutes the inspection.
Reports a break or continue statement inside a finally block. Such statements are very confusing, may hide exceptions, and complicate debugging.
Reports s throw statement inside a finally block. Such throw statements may mask exceptions thrown, and complicate debugging.
Reports an empty try block, which usually indicates an error.
Reports an empty finally block, which usually indicates an error.
Reports a return statement inside a finally block. Such return statements may mask exceptions thrown, and complicate debugging.

Reports a catch parameter that is not used in the corresponding block. The catch parameters named ignore or ignored are ignored.

Use the checkbox below to disable this inspection for catch blocks with comments.
Reports a throw statement whose exceptions are always caught by the containing try statement. Using throw statements as a goto to change the local flow of control is confusing.

group.name: Probable bugs
group.inspection: <html> <body> Reports division by zero or a remainder by zero. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>
Reports a for, while, or do statement which can only exit by throwing an exception. Such statements often indicate coding errors.

Reports a usage of a potentially invalid constructor function, for example: a function that is not a constructor after new, using a constructor's prototype or calling a constructor without new. A constructor function is assumed to have an upper case name (optional) or have an explicit JSDoc @constructor tag.
Reports a comparison with NaN. Comparisons like expr == NaN or expr === NaN are always evaluated to false.

inspection.displayName: 'for' loop where update or condition does not use loop variable

group.inspection: Reports a for loop where the condition or update does not use the for loop variable.
Reports an assignment in the form a =+ b. Suggests replacing with a += b.

Reports an assignment or a function call where the name of the target variable or the function parameter does not match the name of the value assigned to it.

Example:


  var x = 0;
  var y = x;
or 

  var x = 0, y = 0;
  var rc = new Rectangle(y, x, 20, 20);
Here the inspection guesses that x and y are mixed up.

Specify the names that should not be used together. An error is reported if a parameter name or an assignment target name contains words from one group while the name of the assigned or passed variable contains words from another group.
<html> <body> Reports a function which must either recurse infinitely or throw an exception. Such functions may not return normally. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>

Reports a return value of a function that doesn't return anything. Calling of such functions always produces an undefined value and such assignment may indicate an error.

Example:


let a = console.log('foo');

The following usages are ignored:
  • Inside a return statement
  • In some binary operations
  • For overridden non-void functions

Reports a comparison of a typeof expression with a literal string which is not one of the standard types: undefined, object, boolean, number, string, function, or symbol. Such comparisons always return false.

inspection.displayName: Comparison of expressions having incompatible types

group.inspection: <html> <body> Reports a comparison with operands of incompatible types or an operand with a type without possible common values. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>

inspection.displayName: Potentially invalid reference to 'this' from closure

group.inspection:
Reports a this in closure that is used for referencing properties of outer context.

Example:


function Outer() {
  this.outerProp = 1;
  function inner() {
    // bad, because 'outerProp' of Outer
    // won't be updated here
    // on calling 'new Outer()' as may be expected
    this.outerProp = 2;
  }
  inner();
}

inspection.displayName: Potentially invalid reference to 'this' of a class from closure

group.inspection:
Reports an attempt to reference a member of an ECMAScript class via the this. qualifier in a nested function that is not a lambda.
this in a nested function that is not a lambda is the function's own this and doesn't relate to the outer class.

inspection.displayName: Possibly incorrect target of indexed property access

group.inspection: Reports a potentially invalid indexed property access, for example, Array[1].

Reports object allocation where the result of the allocated object is ignored, for example, new Error(); as a statement, without any assignment. Such allocation expressions may indicate an odd object initialization strategy.

inspection.displayName: Suspicious usage of 'bind' with arrow function

group.inspection:
Reports bind used together with an arrow function.
Because arrow functions use lexical this, a bind call will have no effect on them.
See here for details.

Reports a consecutive comma in an array literal. The skipped element accepts the undefined value, but it could be done unintentionally, for example, when commas are at the end of one line and at the beginning of the next one.

inspection.displayName: Equality operator may cause type coercion

group.inspection:
Reports a usage of an equality operator that may cause unexpected type coercions. Suggests replacing == and != with type-safe equality operators === and !==.

Depending on the option selected, one of the following cases will be reported:

  • All usages of == and != operators.
  • All usages except comparison with null. Some code styles allow using x == null as a replacement for x === null || x === undefined.
  • Only suspicious expressions, such as: == or != comparisons with 0, '', null, true, false, or undefined.

group.name: PostgreSQL
group.inspection:
Reports situations when you make SELECT from a function or a DBLINK without an alias with a type (for example, AS t1(s VARCHAR)).

This requirement does not apply to scalar functions.

Example (PostgreSQL):

CREATE FUNCTION produce_a_table() RETURNS RECORD AS $$
SELECT 1;
$$ LANGUAGE sql;
SELECT * FROM produce_a_table() AS s (c1 INT);
SELECT * FROM produce_a_table() AS s (c1);
SELECT * FROM DBLINK('dbname=mydb', 'SELECT proname, prosrc FROM pg_proc') AS t1;

The AS s (c1 INT) has a typed alias, while AS s (c1) and AS t1 do not. In this case, the second call of produce_a_table() and DBLINK() will be highlighted.

group.name: Code style issues

inspection.displayName: Constant on right side of comparison

group.inspection: <!-- Copied from community/plugins/InspectionGadgets/src/inspectionDescriptions/ConstantOnWrongSideOfComparison.html --> <html> <body> Reports a comparison operation with a constant in the right-hand side. According to coding conventions, constants should only be in the left-hand side of comparisons. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>

Reports a statement without a semicolon or a newline at the end.

Select the 'Terminate statements with semicolons' option in Editor | Code Style | JavaScript or TypeScript - Punctuation to report any statement that doesn't end with a semicolon, even if a newline is used. According to some coding styles, semicolons are preferred to line-breaks for consistency with the other languages.
Reports a function call that is used as an argument in another function call, for example, foo(bar())
Reports a if, while, for, or with statements whose body is not a block statement. Using code block in statement bodies is usually safer for downstream maintenance.

Reports an assignment to a property that is not defined in the type of a variable.

Example: 


/**
 * @type {{ property1: string, property2: number }}
 */
let myVariable = create();

myVariable.newProperty = 3; // bad
Reports a function call whose target is another function call, for example, foo().bar()
Reports a chained equality comparison (i.e. a==b==c). Such comparisons are confusing.

inspection.displayName: Redundant braces around arrow function body

group.inspection:
Reports an arrow function whose body only consists of braces and exactly one statement. Suggests converting to concise syntax without braces. 

    let incrementer = (x) => {return x + 1};

After the quick-fix is applied, the code fragment looks as follows:


    let incrementer = (x) => x + 1;

inspection.displayName: 'var' declared not at the beginning of a function

group.inspection:
Checks that declarations of local variables declared with var are at the top of a function scope.

By default, variable declarations are always moved ("hoisted") invisibly to the top of their containing scope when the code is executed. Therefore, declaring them at the top of the scope helps represent this behavior in the code.

Reports redundant parentheses.

In expressions:

var x = ((1) + 2) + 3

In arrow function argument lists:

var incrementer = (x) => x + 1

In TypeScript and Flow type declarations:

type Card = (Suit & Rank) | (Suit & Number)

inspection.displayName: Constant on left side of comparison

group.inspection: <!-- Copied from community/plugins/InspectionGadgets/src/inspectionDescriptions/ConstantOnWrongSideOfComparison.html --> <html> <body> Reports a comparison operation with a constant value in the left-hand side. According to coding conventions, constants should be in the right-hand side of comparisons. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>

group.name: GitHub actions
group.inspection:
Detects dependencies to undefined Jobs in GitHub workflow YML file.

See the GitHub Actions documentation for more information on workflow syntax.

Reports invalid GitHub Actions Expression language standard library function calls

For more information on GitHub Actions Expression language, see the GitHub documentation.

Detects cyclic dependencies for jobs in GitHub workflow YML file.

See the GitHub Actions documentation for more information on workflow syntax.

Reports the absence of mandatory parameters that do not have a default value for an action. It also provides a Quick Fix by adding the missing parameters with an empty value.

For more information on action params, see the GitHub documentation.

Detects unresolved action references in GitHub action and workflow files.

For more information on action references, see the GitHub documentation.

Reports the presence of parameters which are not defined in an action. It also provides a Quick Fix by removing the undefined parameters.

For more information on action params, see the GitHub documentation.

group.name: CSS

inspection.displayName: Property is incompatible with selected browsers

group.inspection: Reports a CSS property that is not supported by the specified browsers. Based on the MDN Compatibility Data.

Reports an rgb(), hsl(), or other color function.

Suggests replacing a color function with an equivalent hexadecimal notation.

Example:

rgb(12, 15, 255)

After the quick-fix is applied:

#0c0fff.

inspection.displayName: Color could be replaced with rgb()

group.inspection:
Reports an hsl() or hwb() color function or a hexadecimal color notation.

Suggests replacing such color value with an equivalent rgb() or rgba() color function.

Example:

#0c0fff

After the quick-fix is applied:

rgb(12, 15, 255).

Reports a duplicated CSS property within a ruleset. Respects shorthand properties.

Example:


.foo {
  margin-bottom: 1px;
  margin-bottom: 1px; /* duplicates margin-bottom */
  margin: 0; /* overrides margin-bottom */
}
<html> <body> Reports a deprecated CSS value. Suggests replacing the deprecated value with its valid equivalent. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>

inspection.displayName: Properties may be safely replaced with a shorthand

group.inspection:
Reports a set of longhand properties. Suggests replacing a complete set of longhand CSS properties with an equivalent shorthand form.

For example, 4 properties: padding-top, padding-right, padding-bottom, and padding-left can be safely replaced with a single padding property.

Note that this inspection doesn't show up if the set of longhand properties is incomplete (e.g. only 3 padding-xxx properties in a ruleset) because switching to a shorthand may change the result. For such cases consider the 'Properties may probably be replaced with a shorthand' inspection.

inspection.displayName: Properties may probably be replaced with a shorthand

group.inspection:
Reports a set of longhand CSS properties and suggests replacing an incomplete set of longhand CSS properties with a shorthand form, which is however not 100% equivalent in this case.

For example, 2 properties: outline-color and outline-style may be replaced with a single outline. Such replacement is not 100% equivalent because shorthands reset all omitted sub-values to their initial states. In this example, switching to the outline shorthand means that outline-width is also set to its initial value, which is medium.

This inspection doesn't handle full sets of longhand properties (when switching to shorthand is 100% safe). For such cases see the 'Properties may be safely replaced with a shorthand' inspection instead.

Reports a CSS class or an element IDs that appears in selectors but is not used in HTML.

Note that complete inspection results are available only when running it via Code | Inspect Code or Code | Analyze Code | Run Inspection by Name. Due to performance reasons, style sheet files are not inspected on the fly.

group.name: Structural search
group.inspection:
Allows configuring Structural Search/Structural Replace templates that you can apply to the file you are editing.

All matches will be highlighted and marked with the template name that you have configured. If you configure the Structural Replace pattern as well, the corresponding replace option will be available as a quick-fix.

group.name: React
group.inspection: Detects HTML elements in JSX files which are not nested properly according to the DOM specification. React reports runtime warnings on incorrectly nested elements.

group.name: XSLT
group.inspection:
Reports missing arguments, passing arguments that are not declared, and passing arguments for parameters more than once in named XSLT template invocations.

Parameters declared with a default value are optional and will not be reported as missing.
<html> <body> Reports duplicate declarations and illegal identifiers in XSLT variables, parameters, and named templates: <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>
<html> <body> Reports shadowed XSLT variables. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>
<html> <body> Reports local variables and parameters that are never used. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>

group.name: Node.js
group.inspection:
Suggests configuring coding assistance for Node.js, for example, require and/or core modules ('path', 'http', 'fs', etc.).

See https://nodejs.org/api/ for the complete list.

group.name: Unused symbols
group.inspection: <html> <body> Reports an unused locally accessible parameter, local variable, function, class, or private member declaration. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>
<html> <body> Reports an unused globally accessible public function, variable, class, or property. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>

Reports a variable whose value is never used after assignment.
Suggests removing the unused variable to shorten the code and to avoid redundant allocations.

The following cases are reported:

  • A variable is never read after assignment.
  • The value of a variable is always overwritten with another assignment before the variable is read next time.
  • The initializer of a variable is redundant (for one of the above-mentioned reasons).

group.name: Markdown
group.inspection:
To ensure consistency between different tools, file links should not contain spaces.

Example:


  [Some file link](some file.md)

A quick-fix replaces spaces with their url-encoded equivalent:


  [Some file link](some%20file.md)
<html> <body> Reports unresolved link labels in Markdown files. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>
<html> <body> Reports unresolved file references in Markdown files. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>
<html> <body> Checks if a particular table of contents section corresponds to the actual structure of the document. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>
<html> <body> Checks if table has correct side borders. For compatibility reasons all table rows should have borders (pipe symbols) at the start and at the end. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>
<html> <body> Reports unresolved header references in Markdown files. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>
<html> <body> Checks if table is correctly formatted. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>

Ordered list items are expected to have straight numeration starting from 1.

The motivation behind this is that most of Markdown processors are ignoring the numbering of ordered lists. A processor will generate an <ol> element for such list, that will number items continuously from 1.

group.name: Data flow
group.inspection:
Reports an unnecessary local variable that does not make a function more comprehensible:
  • a local variable that is immediately returned
  • a local variable that is immediately assigned to another variable and is not used anymore
  • a local variable that always has the same value as another local variable or parameter.

Use the checkbox below to have this inspection ignore variables that are immediately returned or thrown. Some coding styles suggest using such variables for clarity and ease of debugging.

<html> <body> Reports reusing a local variable and overwriting its value with a new value that is not related to the original variable usage. Reusing a local variable in this way may be confusing because the intended semantics of the local variable may vary with each usage. It may also cause bugs, if code changes result in values that were expected to be overwritten while they are actually live. It is good practices to keep variable lifetimes as short as possible, and not reuse local variables for the sake of brevity. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>

group.name: MySQL
group.inspection:
Reports paths that start with the tilde character in LOAD statements.

Example (MySQL):

CREATE TABLE table_name (id int);
LOAD DATA LOCAL INFILE '~/Documents/some_file.txt'
INTO TABLE table_name FIELDS TERMINATED BY ',' LINES TERMINATED BY '\n'
IGNORE 1 LINES;

Instead of the tilde character, use a full path to the file.

Reports invalid usages of UNION in queries.

The inspection works in MySQL versions that are earlier than 8.0.

Example (MySQL):


SELECT * FROM (SELECT 1 UNION (SELECT 1 UNION SELECT 2)) a;

inspection.displayName: Whitespace between the function name and the open parenthesis

group.inspection:
Reports any whitespace in a function call between the function name and the open parenthesis, which is not supported by default.

Example (MySQL):

SELECT MAX (qty) FROM orders;

group.name: ES2015 migration aids

inspection.displayName: Function expression is used instead of arrow function

group.inspection:
Reports a function expression. Suggests converting it to an arrow function.

Example:

arr.map(function(el) {return el + 1})

After applying the quick-fix the code looks as follows:

arr.map(el => el + 1)

Reports a var declaration that is used instead of let or const.
Both let and const are block-scoped and behave more strictly.

Suggests replacing all var declarations with let or const declarations, depending on the semantics of a particular value. The declarations may be moved to the top of the function or placed before the first usage of the variable to avoid Reference errors.
Select the 'Conservatively convert var with Fix all action' option to prevent any changes in these complex cases when using the 'Fix all' action.

Reports a require() statement. Suggests converting it to a require() call with an import statement.

Enable 'Convert require() inside inner scopes with Fix all action' to convert all require() calls inside the nested functions and statements when using the 'Fix all' action.

Please note that converting require() statements inside inner scopes to import statements may cause changes in the semantics of the code. Import statements are static module dependencies and are hoisted, which means that they are moved to the top of the current module. require() calls load modules dynamically. They can be executed conditionally, and their scope is defined by the expression in which they are used.
Clear the 'Convert require() inside inner scopes with Fix all action' checkbox to prevent any changes in these complex cases when using the 'Fix all' action.
Reports a let declaration that can be made const.

Reports a module.export statement. Suggests replacing it with an export or export default statement.

Please note that the quick-fix for converting module.export into export is not available for module.export inside functions or statements because export statements can only be at the top level of a module.

Reports a usage of a for..in loop on an array. Suggests replacing it with a for..of loop.
for..of loops, which are introduced in ECMAScript 6, iterate over iterable objects. For arrays, this structure is preferable to for..in, because it works only with array values but not with array object's properties.

Reports an indexed for loop used on an array. Suggests replacing it with a for..of loop.
for..of loops are introduced in ECMAScript 6 and iterate over iterable objects.

inspection.displayName: String concatenation is used instead of template literal

group.inspection:
Reports a string concatenation. Suggests replacing it with a template literal

Example

 "result: " + a + "."

After applying the quick-fix the code looks as follows:

 `result: ${a}.`

group.name: Validity issues

inspection.displayName: 'this' expression which references the global object

group.inspection: Reports a this expression outside an object literal or a constructor body. Such this expressions reference the top-level "global" JavaScript object, but are mostly useless.

Reports a deprecated octal integer literal prefixed with 0 instead of 0o.
Such literals are not allowed in modern ECMAScript code, and using them in the strict mode is an error.
To force this inspection for ES5 and ES3 language levels, select the 'Warn about obsolete octal literals in ES5- code' checkbox below.

Reports a function that returns a value in some cases while in other cases no value is returned. This usually indicates an error.

Example:


function foo() {
  if (true)
    return 3;
  return;
}

inspection.displayName: String literal which breaks HTML parsing

group.inspection: Reports a string literal that contains a </ sequence. Such strings may result in incorrect parsing of any HTML in which the JavaScript code is embedded.

inspection.displayName: Expression statement which is not assignment or call

group.inspection: <html> <body> Reports an expression statement that is neither an assignment nor a call. Such statements usually indicate an error. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>

<html> <body> Reports a JavaScript reserved word used as a name. The JavaScript specification reserves a number of words which are currently not used as keywords. Using those words as identifiers may result in broken code if later versions of JavaScript start using them as keywords. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>

inspection.displayName: Attempt to assign to const or readonly variable

group.inspection: <html> <body> Reports reassigning a value to a constant or a readonly variable. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>

group.name: Vue
group.inspection: <html> <body> Reports an unrecognized Vue directive. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>

Reports multiple usages of the template or script tag in a Vue file.

Vue Component specification indicates that each *.vue file can contain at most one template or script block at a time.
<html> <body> Reports an unrecognized Vue slot. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>

Reports a Vue component data property that is not a function. Suggests wrapping an object literal with a function.

When defining a component, data must be declared as a function that returns the initial data object, because the same definition will be used for creating numerous instances. If a plain object is still used for data, that very object will be shared by reference across all instances created! With a data function, every time a new instance is created we can simply call it to return a fresh copy of the initial data.
<html> <body> Reports a deprecated Vue symbol. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>
<html> <body> Reports Vue components, which require to be imported in Vue templates. It provides a quick fix to add the missing import. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>

group.name: RegExp
group.inspection:
Reports redundant \d or [:digit:] that are used in one class with \w or [:word:] (\D with \W) and can be removed.

Example:


  [\w\d]

After the quick-fix is applied:


  [\w]

New in 2022.2

Reports redundant character escape sequences that can be replaced with unescaped characters preserving the meaning. Many escape sequences that are necessary outside of a character class are redundant inside square brackets [] of a character class.

Although unescaped opening curly braces { outside of character classes are allowed in some dialects (JavaScript, Python, and so on), it can cause confusion and make the pattern less portable, because there are dialects that require escaping curly braces as characters. For this reason the inspection does not report escaped opening curly braces.

Example:


  \-\;[\.]

After the quick-fix is applied:


  -;[.]

The Ignore escaped closing brackets '}' and ']' option specifies whether to report \} and \] outside of a character class when they are allowed to be unescaped by the RegExp dialect.

New in 2017.3

Reports unnecessary nested character classes.

Example:


  [a-c[x-z]]

After the quick-fix is applied:


  [a-cx-z]

New in 2020.2

Reports escaped meta characters. Some RegExp coding styles specify that meta characters should be placed inside a character class, to make the regular expression easier to understand. This inspection does not warn about the meta character [, ] and ^, because those would need additional escaping inside a character class.

Example:


  \d+\.\d+

After the quick-fix is applied:


  \d+[.]\d+

New in 2017.1

Reports duplicate characters inside a RegExp character class. Duplicate characters are unnecessary and can be removed without changing the semantics of the regex.

Example:


  [aabc]

After the quick-fix is applied:


  [abc]

Reports octal escapes, which are easily confused with back references. Use hexadecimal escapes to avoid confusion.

Example:


  \07

After the quick-fix is applied:


  \x07

New in 2017.1

inspection.displayName: Anonymous capturing group or numeric back reference

group.inspection:
Reports anonymous capturing groups and numeric back references in a RegExp. These are only reported when the RegExp dialect supports named group and named group references. Named groups and named back references improve code readability and are recommended to use instead. When a capture is not needed, matching can be more performant and use less memory by using a non-capturing group, i.e. (?:xxx) instead of (xxx).

Example:


  (\d\d\d\d)\1

A better regex pattern could look like this:


  (?<quad>\d\d\d\d)\k<quad>

New in 2017.2

Reports single char alternation in a RegExp. It is simpler to use a character class instead. This may also provide better matching performance.

Example:


  a|b|c|d

After the quick-fix is applied:


  [abcd]

New in 2017.1

Reports empty branches in a RegExp alternation. An empty branch will only match the empty string, and in most cases that is not what is desired. This inspection will not report a single empty branch at the start or the end of an alternation.

Example:


  (alpha||bravo)

After the quick-fix is applied:


  (alpha|bravo)

New in 2017.2

Reports regular expressions that can be simplified.

Example:


  [a] xx* [ah-hz]

After the quick-fix is applied:


  a x+ [ahz]

New in 2022.1

Reports duplicate branches in a RegExp alternation. Duplicate branches slow down matching and obscure the intent of the expression.

Example:


  (alpha|bravo|charlie|alpha)

After the quick-fix is applied:


  (alpha|bravo|charlie)

New in 2017.1

inspection.displayName: Begin or end anchor in unexpected position

group.inspection:
Reports ^ or \A anchors not at the beginning of the pattern and $, \Z or \z anchors not at the end of the pattern. In the wrong position these RegExp anchors prevent the pattern from matching anything. In case of the ^ and $ anchors, most likely the literal character was meant and the escape forgotten.

Example:


  (Price $10)

New in 2018.1

Reports unnecessary non-capturing groups, which have no influence on the match result.

Example:


  Everybody be cool, (?:this) is a robbery!

After the quick-fix is applied:


  Everybody be cool, this is a robbery!

New in 2021.1

Reports multiple consecutive spaces in a RegExp. Because spaces are not visible by default, it can be hard to see how many spaces are required. The RegExp can be made more clear by replacing the consecutive spaces with a single space and a counted quantifier.

Example:


  (     )

After the quick-fix is applied:


  ( {5})

New in 2017.1
<html> <body> Custom Regex Inspection <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>

Reports back references that will not be resolvable at runtime. This means that the back reference can never match anything. A back reference will not be resolvable when the group is defined after the back reference, or if the group is defined in a different branch of an alternation.

Example of a group defined after its back reference:


  \1(abc)

Example of a group and a back reference in different branches:


  a(b)c|(xy)\1z

New in 2022.1

group.name: Control flow issues
group.inspection: Reports an if statement with identical then and else branches. Such statements are almost certainly an error.
Reports an unnecessary continue statement at the end of a loop. Suggests removing such statements.
Reports an error caused by invoking a method, accessing a property, or calling a function on an object that is undefined or null.
Reports a for, while, or do statement whose bodies are guaranteed to execute at most once. Normally, this indicates an error.
<html> <body> Reports an unused label. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>

Reports an if statement with too many branches. Such statements may be confusing, and often indicate inadequate levels of design abstraction.

Use the field below to specify the maximum number of branches expected.

inspection.displayName: 'for' loop may be replaced by 'while' loop

group.inspection:
Reports a for loop that contains neither initialization nor an update component. Suggests replacing the loop with a simpler while statement.

Example:


  for(; exitCondition(); ) {
    process();
  }

After the quick-fix is applied the result looks like:


  while(exitCondition()) {
    process();
  }

Use the checkbox below if you wish this inspection to ignore for loops with trivial or non-existent conditions.

Reports a typeof or instanceof unsound type guard check. The typeof x type guard can be unsound in one of the following two cases:
  • typeof x never corresponds to the specified value (for example, typeof x === 'number' when x is of the type 'string | boolean')
  • typeof x always corresponds to the specified value (for example, typeof x === 'string' when x is of the type 'string')

The x instanceof A type guard can be unsound in one of the following two cases:
  • The type of x is not related to A
  • The type of x is A or a subtype of A

Reports a conditional expression of the form 

condition ? true : false
condition ? false : true

These expressions may be safely converted to 


condition
!condition

Reports an unnecessary return statement, that is, a return statement that returns no value and occurs just before the function would have "fallen through" the bottom. These statements may be safely removed.
Reports a ternary conditional expression with identical then and else branches.

Reports duplicate conditions in different branches of an if statement. Duplicate conditions usually represent programmer oversight.

Example:


  if (a) {
    ...
  } else if (a) {
    ...
  }

<html> <body> Reports a tail recursion, that is, when a function calls itself as its last action before returning. A tail recursion can always be replaced by looping, which will be considerably faster. Some JavaScript engines perform this optimization, while others do not. Thus, tail recursive solutions may have considerably different performance characteristics in different environments. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>
Reports a conditional expression in the format true? result1: result2 or false? result1: result2. Suggests simplifying the expression.

Reports a pointless or pointlessly complicated boolean expression or statement.

Example: 


  let a = !(false && x);
  let b = false || x;

After the quick fix is applied the result looks like: 


  let a = true;
  let b = x;
Reports a labeled break statement whose labels may be removed without changing the flow of control.
<html> <body> Reports code that can never be executed, which almost certainly indicates an error <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>
Reports a labeled continue statement whose labels may be removed without changing the flow of control.

Reports an if statement that can be simplified to a single assignment or a return statement.

Example:


if(foo())
 {
  return true;
 }
 else
 {
   return false;
 }

After applying the quick-fix the code looks as follows:

 return foo();

group.name: Switch statement issues
group.inspection:
Reports an unreachable case branch of a switch statement.

Example:


/**
 * @param {('foo' | 'bar')} p
 */
function foo(p) {
    switch (p) {
        case 'foo': break;
        case 'bar': break;
        case 'baz': break; // unreachable
    }
}
Reports a switch statement without a default clause when some possible values are not enumerated.
Reports a switch statement where the default case comes before another case instead of being the very last case, which may cause confusion.
Reports a switch statement that is nested in another switch statement. Nested switch statements may be very confusing, particularly if indenting is inconsistent.
Reports a switch statement on a variable of the type enum or union when the statement doesn't cover some value options from the type.

inspection.displayName: 'switch' statement is redundant and can be replaced

group.inspection: Reports a switch statement with an empty body, or with only one case branch, or with a default branch only.

Reports a labeled statement inside a switch statement, which often results from a typo.

Example:


    switch(x)
    {
        case 1:
        case2:   //typo!
        case 3:
            break;
    }
Reports a duplicated case label on a switch statement, which normally indicates an error.
Reports a switch statement where control can proceed from a branch to the next one. Such "fall-through" often indicates an error, for example, a missing break or return.

inspection.displayName: Variable is declared and being used in different 'case' clauses

group.inspection:
Reports a variable that is declared in one case clause of a switch statement but is used in another case clause of the same statement. For block-scoped variables, this results in throwing a ReferenceError. For var variables, it indicates a potential error.

Disable the inspection for var variables if this pattern is used intentionally.

group.name: JSONPath
group.inspection: Reports an unknown name in a JSONPath function call instead of known standard function names: concat, keys, length, min, max, avg, stddev, sum.

inspection.displayName: Unknown property key used for JSONPath evaluate expression

group.inspection: <html> <body> Reports a key in a JSONPath expression that is missing in the source JSON document to evaluate. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>
Reports an unknown operator on a JSONPath expression instead of one of the standard ones: in, nin, subsetof, anyof, noneof, size, empty, contains.

group.name: Sass/SCSS
group.inspection:
Reports a reference to a variable, mixin, or function that is declared in another file but this file isn't explicitly imported in the current file.

Example:


* {
  margin: $var-in-other-file;
}

Reports an unresolved Sass/SCSS variable reference.

Example:


* {
  margin: $unknown-var;
}

Reports an unresolved Sass/SCSS mixin reference.

Example:


* {
  @include unknown-mixin;
}

Reports an unresolved Sass/SCSS placeholder selector reference.

Example:


* {
  @extend %unknown-placeholder-selector;
}

group.name: General
group.inspection:
Reports unresolved references injected by Language Injections.

Example:


    @Language("file-reference")
    String fileName = "/home/user/nonexistent.file"; // highlighted if file doesn't exist

Reports formatting issues that appear if your code doesn't follow your project's code style settings.

This inspection is not compatible with languages that require third-party formatters for code formatting, for example, Go or C with CLangFormat enabled.

Reports TODO comments in your code.

You can configure the format for TODO comments in Settings | Editor | TODO.

Enable the Only warn on TODO comments without any details option to only warn on empty TODO comments, that don't provide any description on the task that should be done. Disable to report all TODO comments.

Reports files that were explicitly re-assigned to Plain Text File Type. This association is unnecessary because the platform auto-detects text files by content automatically.

You can dismiss this warning by removing the file type association in Settings | Editor | File Types | Text.

inspection.displayName: Line is longer than allowed by code style

group.inspection: Reports lines that are longer than the Hard wrap at parameter specified in Settings | Editor | Code Style | General.

Reports files with line separators different from the ones that are specified in the project's settings.

For example, the inspection will be triggered if you set the line separator to \n in Settings | Editor | Code Style | Line separator, while the file you are editing uses \r\n as a line separator.

The inspection also warns you about mixed line separators within a file.

Reports the following problems:
  • Tabs used for indentation when the code style is configured to use only spaces.
  • Spaces used for indentation when the code style is configured to use only tabs.
  • Spaces used for indentation and tabs used for alignment when the code style is configured to use smart tabs.

Reports empty directories.

Available only from Code | Inspect Code or Code | Analyze Code | Run Inspection by Name and isn't reported in the editor.

Use the Only report empty directories located under a source folder option to have only directories under source roots reported.

Reports usages of the following elements that can be safely removed because the inspection they affect is no longer applicable in this context:
  • @SuppressWarning annotation, or
  • // noinspection line comment, or
  • /** noinspection */ JavaDoc comment

Example:


public class C {
 // symbol is already private,
 // but annotation is still around
  @SuppressWarnings({"WeakerAccess"})
  private boolean CONST = true;
  void f() {
    CONST = false;
  }
}

Reports issues essential to this file (e.g., syntax errors) in the result of a batch code inspection run. These issues are usually always highlighted in the editor and can't be configured, unlike inspections. These options control the scope of checks performed by this inspection:
  • Option "Report syntax errors": report parser-related issues.
  • Option "Report issues from language-specific annotators": report issues found by annotators configured for the relevant language. See Custom Language Support: Annotators for details.
  • Option "Report other highlighting problems": report issues specific to the language of the current file (e.g., type mismatches or unreported exceptions). See Custom Language Support: Highlighting for details.

Reports duplicated blocks of code from the selected scope: the same file or the entire project.

The inspection features quick-fixes that help you to set the size of detected duplicates, navigate to repetitive code fragments, and compare them in a tool window.

The inspection options allow you to select the scope of the reported duplicated fragments and set the initial size for the duplicated language constructs.

You can also configure the constructs that you want to anonymize in File | Settings | Editor | Duplicates.

group.name: HTTP Client
group.inspection: <html> <body> Highlights references to non-existent Auth configurations. Suggests creating a new one in the current environment. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>

Reports unknown HTTP headers that do not match any publicly known headers. The quick fix suggests adding the header to the list of custom headers when the Use custom HTTP headers option is enabled. HTTP headers from the list of custom headers will not trigger the inspection.
Reports an explicitly set Content-Length header. The header is redundant because HTTP Client uses the actual request body length.
Reports inappropriate usage of HTTP protocol keyword, e.g. HTTP/2, with non-HTTP method requests. Such a usage will be ignored.
<html> <body> Highlights request name in run block which has no specified import file. Suggests adding import for the file which contains this named request. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>

inspection.displayName: Missing request separator in YAML body

group.inspection: Reports possible requests in injected YAML body where request separator ### is missing. The quick fix suggests adding the separator ### before the request.

inspection.displayName: Missing request separator in HTML/XML body

group.inspection: Reports possible requests in injected XML/HTML body where request separator ### is missing. The quick fix suggests adding the separator ### before the request.
<html> <body> Highlights already defined import. Suggests removing duplicated import definition. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>

Reports a $placeholder inside a request.

A $placeholder to be replaced by the user is created automatically when a tool cannot recognize a part of a request. For example, a request mapping /aaaa/*/bbb will be generated as GET localhost/aaaa/{{$placeholder}}/bbb.

inspection.displayName: Missing request separator in JSON body

group.inspection: Reports possible requests in injected JSON body where request separator ### is missing. The quick fix suggests adding the separator ### before the request.

Reports Auth configuration the following problems in HTTP Client environment files:
  • Missing properties in Auth configuration
  • Auth/Security configuration placed in private environment file

Detects '+' in an encoded query string. It is ambiguous whether it should be encoded as space or as a '+' character.

Example:


  GET https://example.com/api?name=John+Doe%40example.com

After the quick-fix is applied


  GET https://example.com/api?name=John%20Doe%40example.com
<html> <body> Highlights spaces inside URL path segments. HTTP Client will ignore them. For better composing use Split Lines action. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>
Reports variables which should be double-quoted in json body. The quick fix suggests wrap variable with double quotes "{{variable}}".
<html> <body> Reports possible custom HTTP methods. The quick fix suggests adding the custom HTTP method to project settings. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>

Reports variables undeclared in the current environment HTTP Client.

Executing requests with undeclared variables probably fail. Consider adding a variable to the environment or selecting an environment with this variable.

Inspection doesn't report variables in request bodies, because it can be a valid syntax of the body.

Some variables may be not reported as unresolved, because they are declared in response or pre-request handler scripts via client.global.set or request.variables.set functions call.

group.name: Probable bugs
group.inspection:
Reports a non-integer length in pixels.

Example:

 width: 3.14px

Reports a multi-line selector. Most likely this means that several single-line selectors are actually intended but a comma is missing at the end of one or several lines.

Example:


input /* comma has probably been forgotten */
.button {
  margin: 1px;
}

Verifies that the font-family property contains a generic font family name as a fallback alternative.

Generic font family names are: serif, sans-serif, cursive, fantasy, and monospace.

group.name: RELAX NG
group.inspection: Reports an unresolved reference to a named pattern (define) in RELAX-NG files that use XML syntax. Suggests creating the referenced define element.
Reports an unused named pattern (define) in a RELAX-NG file (XML or Compact Syntax). define elements that are used through an include in another file are ignored.

group.name: Angular
group.inspection: Reports a problem with a i18n-* attribute.
Reports an invalid assignment of an animation trigger. To attach an animation to an element, use [@triggerName]="expression" or an attribute without a value @triggerName.

inspection.displayName: Unused import in an Angular component declaration

group.inspection: <html> <body> Reports unused imports in Angular components. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>

inspection.displayName: Missing or invalid component, directive or pipe declaration in a module

group.inspection: <html> <body> Reports a non-standalone Angular component, directive, or pipe that is not declared in any module or is declared in multiple modules. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>

Suggests using the ng add command to install the dependency.

ng add will use the package manager to download it and invoke a schematic which can update your project with configuration changes, add additional dependencies (e.g. polyfills), or scaffold package-specific initialization code.
<html> <body> Reports a mismatch between actual and expected directive binding type. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>

inspection.displayName: Invalid usage of imports in non-standalone components

group.inspection: <html> <body> Reports usages of imports property in non-standalone component decorators. Imports can be used only in standalone components. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>
<html> <body> Reports issues with triggers in `on` parameters in `@defer` block. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>
<html> <body> Reports a missing event handler statement for an event binding. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>

inspection.displayName: Inaccessible component member or directive input

group.inspection: <html> <body> Reports access to invisible (private or protected) component member or directive input from an Angular template. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>

inspection.displayName: Issues with ngSrc usage in img tags

group.inspection:
Reports issues related to usage of ngSrc (NgOptimizedDirective) on img tags.

Following issues are reported:

  • img tags, which use src instead of ngSrc
  • lack of width and height, or fill attributes when ngSrc is used
  • width or height, and fill attributes being present on the same element when ngSrc is used
<html> <body> Reports an export of an undeclared or unimported component, directive, or pipes from an Angular module. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>
<html> <body> Reports a missing binding for a required directive input. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>
Reports that the type of variable to iterate over does not have [Symbol.iterator]() method, which returns an iterator.
Reports illegal access to the template variable within @for loop track expression.

inspection.displayName: Recursive import or export of an Angular module or a standalone component

group.inspection: <html> <body> Reports a cyclic dependency between Angular modules or standalone components. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>

inspection.displayName: Unbound or ambiguous template reference variable

group.inspection: Reports a template reference variable that is not assigned to a directive when using exportAs or is assigned to multiple directives.
Reports a component that doesn’t have an associated template or uses both template and templateUrl properties.
<html> <body> Reports problems with Angular blocks. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>
Reports a text or tag occurrence inside a <ng-content> tag used for content projection.
Reports a component that is matched on an embedded template element <ng-template> or multiple components matched on any other element.
<html> <body> Reports a tag defined by a component or directive out of the current scope. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>
Reports an invalid selector property of a component or directive.
<html> <body> Reports an undefined property, event, or structural directive bindings on elements. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>
<html> <body> Reports problems with Angular expression syntax, which is not supported in an older version of Angular. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>
Reports a binding to an event property or attribute, for example, [onclick] or [attr.onclick] instead of (click).
Reports an invalid Angular component specified in the module’s bootstrap or entryComponents property.
<html> <body> Reports an unresolved pipe. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>

inspection.displayName: Multiple structural directives on one element

group.inspection: Reports multiple structural directives (*ngIf, *ngFor, etc.) on one element.

<html> <body> Reports any symbol that is declared, imported or exported by an Angular module or standalone component that is not a module, component, directive, or pipe or can’t be used in the context of the property. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>
<html> <body> Reports problems with @let declaration usages. <!-- tooltip end --></body> </html>
